article.title: Dogecoin
article.text:
{{pp-protected|reason=[[Wikipedia:General sanctions/Blockchain and cryptocurrencies]]|small=yes}} {{Infobox cryptocurrency | currency_name = Dogecoin | image_1 = Dogecoin_Logo.png | image_2 = | image_width_1 = 150 | image_width_2 = 110 | image_title_1 = | symbol = [[Eth|Ð]] | ticker_symbol = DOGE | coin_definition = [[Open source]] peer-to-peer digital currency | white_paper = | implementations = | initial_release_version = | initial_release_date = {{Start date and age|2013|12|06}} | code_repository = | status = active | latest_release_version = | latest_release_date = | forked_from = | programming_languages = | operating_system = [[Microsoft Windows]],
[[Linux]],
[[IOS]],
[[Android (operating system)|Android]] | author = Billy Markus, Jackson Palmer | developer = Billy Markus | source_model = Open source | license = | website = https://dogecoin.com/ | block_explorer = https://dogechain.info/ | ledger_genesis = | hash_function = Scrypt-based | issuance = | timestamping = | block_time = 1 minute | block_reward = As of February 2018, the current block reward is about 10000 Dogecoins. | circulating_supply = As of February 2018, over 113 billion coins had been mined. | total_supply = Limitless | exchange_rate = Floating | market_cap = }} '''Dogecoin''' ({{IPAc-en|'|d|oʊ|ʒ|k|ɔɪ|n|}} {{Respell|DOHZH|koyn}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.dailydot.com/unclick/how-to-say-dogecoin-pronunciation/|title=How do you pronounce 'Dogecoin'?|date=2014-04-24|website=The Daily Dot|language=en|access-date=2018-12-21}}, code: '''DOGE''', symbol: '''Ð''' and '''D''') is a [[cryptocurrency]] featuring a likeness of the [[Shiba Inu]] dog from the "[[Doge (meme)|Doge]]" [[Internet meme]] as its logo.{{Cite news |last1=Roose |first1=Kevin |title=Is There a Cryptocurrency Bubble? Just Ask Doge. |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=2017-09-15 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/15/business/cryptocurrency-bubble-doge.html |issn=0362-4331 |df=mdy-all }}[https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3091219 ''A History of Dogecoin.''] Dogecoin Analysis Report. Social Science Research Network (SSRN). Accessed 28 December 2017.{{cite web | url=https://www.digitaltrends.com/social-media/wow-dogecoin-bitcoin/|title= Wow. Dogecoin is the most Internet thing to happen, ever. | author= Andrew Couts | publisher=[[Digital Trends]]|date=December 12, 2013 |accessdate=December 12, 2013 }} Introduced as a "joke currency" on 6 December 2013, Dogecoin quickly developed its own [[online community]] and reached a capitalization of [[United States dollar|US$]]60 million in January 2014.{{cite web|author=Stephen Hutcheon|title=The rise and rise of dogecoin, the internet's hottest cryptocurrency|url=https://www.smh.com.au/technology/technology-news/the-rise-and-rise-of-dogecoin-the-internets-hottest-cryptocurrency-20140124-31d24.html|work=Sydney Morning Herald|publisher=[[Fairfax Media]]|accessdate=April 5, 2014}} Compared with other cryptocurrencies, Dogecoin had a fast initial coin production schedule: 100 billion coins were in circulation by mid-2015, with an additional 5.256 billion coins every year thereafter. {{As of|2015|06|30}}, the 100 billionth Dogecoin had been mined. While there are few mainstream commercial applications, the currency has gained traction as an Internet [[Gratuity|tipping]] system, in which [[social media]] users grant Dogecoin tips to other users for providing interesting or noteworthy content.{{cite web |url=https://www.abc.net.au/pm/content/2013/s3931812.htm |title=The rise and rise of the Dogecoin and internet tipping culture |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |date=24 January 2014|accessdate=March 4, 2015}} Dogecoin is referred to as an [[altcoin]].{{cite news|last1=Kaminska|first1=Izabella|title=Why it’s tough being in an altcoin cartel|url=https://ftalphaville.ft.com/2014/01/24/1750472/why-its-tough-being-in-an-altcoin-cartel/|accessdate=6 June 2018|work=FT|date=24 January 2014}} ==Overview and history== Dogecoin was created by programmer Billy Markus from [[Portland, Oregon]], who hoped to create a fun cryptocurrency that could reach a broader demographic than [[Bitcoin]]. In addition, he wanted to distance it from the controversial history of other coins.{{cite web|url=https://motherboard.vice.com/en_us/article/dogecoins-founders-believe-in-the-power-of-meme-currencies|title=Such Weird: The Founders of Dogecoin See the Meme Currency's Tipping Point|first=|date=|publisher=[[Vice Media]]|author=Patrick McGuire|work=Motherboard|accessdate=December 23, 2013}} At the same time, Jackson Palmer, a member of [[Adobe Systems]]' marketing department in [[Sydney, Australia|Sydney]], was encouraged on Twitter by a student at [[Front Range Community College]] to make the idea a reality.{{cite web | url=http://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-dogecoin-2013-12|title= What is Dogecoin? | author= Rob Wile | publisher=[[Business Insider]]|date=December 19, 2013 |accessdate=December 19, 2013 }} After receiving several mentions on [[Twitter]], Palmer purchased the domain dogecoin.com and added a splash screen, which featured the coin's logo and scattered [[Comic Sans]] text. Markus saw the site linked in an IRC chat room, and started efforts to create the currency after reaching out to Palmer. Markus based Dogecoin on an existing cryptocurrency, Luckycoin,{{cite web|url=http://www.seattlepi.com/technology/heavy/article/Dogecoin-5-Fast-Facts-You-Need-to-Know-5079680.php|title=Dogecoin: 5 Fast Facts You Need to Know|publisher=}} which features a randomized reward that is received for mining a block, although this behavior was later changed to a static block reward in March 2014. In turn, Luckycoin is based on [[Litecoin]], which also uses [[scrypt]] technology in its [[proof-of-work system|proof-of-work]] algorithm. The use of scrypt means that miners cannot use [[SHA-2|SHA-256]] bitcoin mining equipment, and that dedicated [[field-programmable gate array|FPGA]] and [[ASIC]] devices used for mining are complicated to create. Dogecoin was officially launched on December 6, 2013.{{cite web | url=http://washingtonexaminer.com/internet-gold-doge-bitcoin-dogecoin/article/2541000?custom_click=rss|title= Internet gold: Doge + Bitcoin = Dogecoin | author= Ashe Schow | publisher=[[Washington Examiner]]|date=December 19, 2013 |accessdate=December 19, 2013 }} The Dogecoin network was originally intended to produce 100 billion Dogecoins, but later, it was announced that the Dogecoin network would produce infinite Dogecoins.{{cite web | url=http://www.heavy.com/tech/2013/12/dogecoin-what-is-shibe-cryptocurrenc/|title= Dogecoin: 5 Fast Facts You Need to Know. | author= Danny Vega | publisher=[[Heavy.com]]|date=December 9, 2013 |accessdate=December 9, 2013 }}{{cite web | url=http://www.dailydot.com/business/shibe-meme-dogecoin-currency/ | title=With its own cryptocurrency, Doge has officially conquered 2013| author=Miles Klee | publisher=[[The Daily Dot]]|date=December 10, 2013 |accessdate=December 10, 2013 }} On December 19, 2013, Dogecoin jumped nearly 300 percent in value in 72 hours, rising from [[USD|US$]]0.00026 to $0.00095,{{cite web | url=http://www.digitaltrends.com/cool-tech/dogecoin-price-value-jump-bitcoin|title= To the moon! DogeCoin fetches 300 percent jump in value in 24 hours.| author= Andrew Couts | publisher=[[Digital Trends]]|date=December 19, 2013 |accessdate=December 19, 2013 }} with a volume of billions of Dogecoins per day. This growth occurred during a time when Bitcoin and many other cryptocurrencies were reeling from China's decision to forbid Chinese banks from investing into the Bitcoin economy.{{cite web | url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/what-dogecoin-meme-that-became-hot-new-virtual-currency-1429847|title= What is Dogecoin? The Meme that Became the Hot New Virtual Currency.| author= David Gilbert | publisher=[[International Business Times]]|date=December 20, 2013 |accessdate=December 20, 2013 }} Three days later, Dogecoin experienced its first major crash by dropping by 80% due to this event and due to large mining pools seizing opportunity in exploiting the very little computing power required at the time to mine Dogecoin.{{cite web | url=http://www.businessinsider.com/dogecoin-crashed-this-weekend-2013-12|title= Dogecoin Prices Crashed This Weekend| author= Rob Wile| publisher=[[Business Insider]]|date=December 22, 2013 |accessdate=December 22, 2013 }} On December 25, 2013, the first major theft of Dogecoin occurred when millions of coins were stolen during a hack on the online [[cryptocurrency wallet]] platform Dogewallet.{{cite web | url=https://gizmodo.com/millions-of-meme-based-dogecoins-stolen-on-christmas-da-1489819762|title= Millions of Meme-Based Dogecoins Stolen on Christmas Day| author= Ashley Feinberg| publisher=[[Gizmodo]]|date=December 26, 2013 |accessdate=December 26, 2013 }} The hacker gained access to the platform's filesystem and modified its send/receive page to send any and all coins to a static address.{{cite web | url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/12/25/dogecoin-hack/|title= Such Hack. Many Dogecoin. Very Disappear. So Gone. Wow. | author= Catherine Shu| publisher=[[TechCrunch]]|date=December 25, 2013 |accessdate=December 25, 2013 }}{{cite web | url=http://www.latimes.com/business/technology/la-fi-tn-dogecoin-theft-currency-bitcoin-20131226,0,2575238.story#axzz2ojLWuO2X|title= Millions of Dogecoins, currency based on a meme, are reported stolen | author= Salvador Rodriguez| publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=December 26, 2013 |accessdate=December 26, 2013 }} This hacking incident spiked tweets about Dogecoin, making it the most mentioned altcoin on Twitter at the time, although it was in reference to a negative event. To help those who lost funds on Dogewallet after its breach, the Dogecoin community started an initiative named "SaveDogemas" to help donate coins to those who had them stolen. Approximately one month later, enough money was donated to cover all of the coins that were stolen.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitaltrends.com/cool-tech/dogecoin-dogewallet-hack-save-dogemas/|title=Such generosity! After Dogewallet heist, Dogecoin community aims to reimburse victims|date=December 27, 2013|publisher=}} On January 2014, the trading volume of Dogecoin briefly surpassed that of Bitcoin and all other crypto-currencies combined, however, its market capitalization remained substantially behind that of Bitcoin. {{As of|2015|1|25}}, Dogecoin had a market capitalization of [[USD]] 13.5 million. April 2015 Jackson Palmer announced he is taking an "extended leave of absence" from the cryptocurrency community.{{cite web | url=http://www.coindesk.com/dogecoin-founder-bitcoin-toxic/|title= DDogecoin Founder Exits Crypto Community Citing 'Toxic' Culture | author= Pete Rizzo | publisher=[[Coindesk]]|date=April 24, 2015 |accessdate=April 24, 2015 }} In January 2018, Dogecoin reached $2 billion market cap.{{Citation needed|date=November 2018}} ==Fundraising== ===2014 Winter Olympics=== The Dogecoin community and foundation have encouraged fundraising for charities and other notable causes. On January 19, 2014, a fundraiser was established by the Dogecoin community to raise $50,000 for the [[Jamaican Bobsled Team]], which had qualified for, but could not afford to go to, the [[Sochi Winter Olympics]]. By the second day, $36,000 worth of Dogecoin was donated and the Dogecoin to bitcoin exchange rate rose by 50%.{{cite news|last1=Rodriguez|first1=Salvador|title=Jamaican bobsled team boosts value of Dogecoin, currency based on meme|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/technology/la-fi-tn-jamaican-bobsled-dogecoin-currency-meme-20140120-story.html|work=Los Angeles Times|date=20 January 2014}} The Dogecoin community also raised funds for a second Sochi athlete [[Shiva Keshavan]].{{cite web|author=Devin Coldewey |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/technology/dogecoin-cryptocurrency-donors-help-send-indian-athletes-sochi-2D12024654 |title=Dogecoin cryptocurrency donors help send Indian athletes to Sochi |publisher=NBC News.com |date=January 29, 2014 |accessdate=February 2, 2014}} ===Doge4Water=== Inspired by the Winter Olympics fundraiser and smaller charity fundraising successes, the Dogecoin Foundation, led by [[Eric Nakagawa]], began collecting donations to build a well in the Tana river basin in Kenya in cooperation with [[Charity: Water]]. They set out to raise a total of 40,000,000 ($30,000 at the time) Dogecoin before [[World Water Day]] (March 22). The campaign succeeded, collecting donations from more than 4,000 donors, including one anonymous benefactor who donated 14,000,000 Dogecoin (approx. $11,000).{{cite web|author=David Gilbert |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/most-valuable-tweet-history-donates-11000-worth-dogecoin-kenyan-water-charity-1440565 |title='Most Valuable Tweet in History' Donates $11,000 Worth of Dogecoin to Kenyan Water Charity |publisher=IB Times |date=March 17, 2014 |accessdate=May 25, 2014}} ===NASCAR=== On March 25, 2014, the Dogecoin community successfully raised 67.8 million Dogecoins (around $55,000 at the time) in an effort to sponsor [[NASCAR]] driver [[Josh Wise]]. Wise ran with a Dogecoin/[[Reddit]]-sponsored paint scheme at the [[2014 Aaron's 499|Aaron's 499]] at [[Talladega Superspeedway]].{{cite web|last=Estrada|first=Chris|url=http://motorsportstalk.nbcsports.com/2014/03/25/nascar-fans-on-reddit-use-dogecoin-to-sponsor-josh-wise/|title=NASCAR fans on Reddit use DogeCoin to sponsor Josh Wise|publisher=[[NBC Sports]]|date=March 26, 2014|accessdate=March 26, 2014}} On May 4, 2014, Wise and his car were featured for nearly a minute, during which the race commentators discussed Dogecoin and the crowdfunding effort, while finishing twentieth and narrowly avoiding multiple wrecks.{{cite web|last=Stuckey|first=Daniel|title=Talladega Shibe: The Dogecar's NASCAR Highlights|url=http://motherboard.vice.com/read/talladega-shibe-josh-wises-highlights-in-the-dogecar|accessdate=May 6, 2014}} On May 16, 2014, Wise won a spot at the [[2014 NASCAR Sprint All-Star Race|Sprint All-Star Race]] through an online fan vote beating household name [[Danica Patrick]], largely due to the efforts of the Dogecoin Reddit community. He finished the race in fifteenth, the last car running.{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nascar/2014/05/16/josh-wise-beats-danica-patrick-in-all-star-race-fan-vote-dogecoin/9197981/|title=Josh Wise wins fan vote, beats Danica Patrick|author=Mike Hembree|date=May 16, 2014|accessdate=May 18, 2014|publisher=USA Today}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.polygon.com/2014/5/18/5728334/dogecoin-nascar-video-game-dlc|title=Dogecoin, NASCAR's strangest hood sponsor, will appear in its official video game|publisher=Polygon|author=Owen S. Good|date=May 18, 2014|accessdate=May 18, 2014}} The following race in the [[2014 Coca-Cola 600|Coca-Cola 600]], Wise debuted a Dogecoin/Reddit.com helmet. Wise later announced he would run the car again at the [[2014 Toyota/Save Mart 350|Toyota/Save Mart 350]] as a thank-you gift to the community and the [[2014 GEICO 500|GEICO 500]]. He finished twenty-eighth in the race due in part to a refueling issue; he was in twelfth place after a gas-and-go pit stop, but the gas can did not engage long enough, resulting in a second pit stop that took him towards the back of the pack. The developer of the ''[[NASCAR '14]]'' video game announced that they are looking into adding the Dogecoin car as a drivable car in an upcoming DLC.{{Cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2014/04/24/tech/web/nascar-dogecoin-talladega/|title=Reddit, Dogecoin support NASCAR racer at Talladega|date=April 24, 2014|accessdate=May 18, 2014|publisher=CNN|author=Larry Frum|quote= Fans of the NASCAR '14 video game will also get the chance to race the Dogecoin car for themselves when it is added in an upcoming DLC pack. In fact, they have featured the scheme on a DLC pack that costs $0.99 on the Xbox 360 and the Xbox One.}} ==Use and exchanges== Several online exchanges offer DOGE/[[Bitcoin|BTC]] and DOGE/[[Litecoin|LTC]] trading. Three exchanges, Mengmengbi, Bter and BTC38, offer DOGE/[[Renminbi|CNY]] trading. On January 8, 2014, AltQuick.co was the first exchange to launch DOGE/[[United States dollar|USD]] exchange. On January 30, 2014, Canada-based exchange Vault of Satoshi also announced DOGE/USD and DOGE/[[Canadian dollar|CAD]] trading.{{cite news|first=Danny|last=Bradbury|url=http://www.coindesk.com/vault-of-satoshi-new-altcoin-support/ |title=Vault of Satoshi rolls out new altcoin support |work=Coindesk|date=January 29, 2014}} On February 2014, Hong Kong-based exchange [[Asia Nexgen]] announced that they would support the trading of Dogecoins in all major currencies. China-based exchange BTC38 also added their support on the Dogecoin exchange, boosting the market capitalization over 24 hours.{{cite news|first=Pete|last=Rizzo|date=February 13, 2014|url=http://www.coindesk.com/asia-exchange-addition-dogecoin-price-surge/ |title=Asian exchange additions drive dogecoin price surge |work=Coindesk}}{{cite news|first=Alistair|last=Charlton|date=February 13, 2014|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/cryptocurrency-news-round-london-bitcoin-atm-update-dogecoin-joins-two-exchanges-1436232 |title=Cryptocurrency news round-up: London bitcoin ATM update and dogecoin joins two exchanges |work=International Business Times}} In the first day of trading, Dogecoin was the second-most traded currency on the platform, after Bitcoin. On September 2014, UK-based exchange Yacuna began offering DOGE/EUR and DOGE/GBP trading.{{cite news|title=How to Buy Bitcoin in the UK|url=http://www.coindesk.com/information/buy-bitcoin-uk/|newspaper=Coindesk|date=2014}} On January 31, 2014, trading volume across the major exchanges was valued at $1.05 million USD. The market cap was [[USD]]$60 million. Three exchanges accounted for the majority of volume: Bter (60%), Cryptsy (23%), and Vircurex (10%). The most traded currency pairs were DOGE/BTC (50%), DOGE/CNY (44%) and DOGE/LTC (6%). Trading physical, tangible items in exchange for DOGE takes place on online communities such as [[Reddit]] and [[Twitter]], where users frequently share currency-related information.{{cite web | url=https://www.theverge.com/2013/12/16/5216862/bitcoin-is-so-2013-dogecoin-is-new-crypto-currency-on-the-block|title= Bitcoin is so 2013: Dogecoin is the new cryptocurrency on the block| author= Nathan Ingraham | publisher=[[The Verge]]|date=December 16, 2013 |accessdate=December 16, 2013 }}{{cite web | url=http://www.complex.com/tech/2013/12/dogecoin-on-reddit|title= Move Over Bitcoin: Dogecoin is Here| author= J. Duaine Hahn | publisher=Complex Tech|date=December 16, 2013 |accessdate=December 16, 2013 }} The first Dogecoin ATM was demoed at Coinfest in Vancouver in February 2014.{{cite news|last=Hajdarbegovic|first=Nermin|title=DIY Dogecoin ATM demos at CoinFest Vancouver|url=http://www.coindesk.com/diy-dogecoin-atm-demos-coinfest-vancouver/|accessdate=March 17, 2014|newspaper=Coindesk|date=February 18, 2014}} Two Bitcoin ATMs supporting Dogecoins and other altcoins opened in [[Tijuana, Mexico]] on March 17, 2014.{{cite news|last=Hajdarbegovic|first=Nermin|title=Mexico’s first bitcoin ATMs will also deal in altcoins|url=http://www.coindesk.com/mexicos-first-bitcoin-atms-will-also-deal-altcoins/|accessdate=March 17, 2014|newspaper=Coindesk|date=March 17, 2014}} Dogecoin has also been used to try to sell a house,{{cite web|last=Imam|first=Jareen|title=Man selling home for $135,000 in Dogecoins|url=http://www.cnn.com/2014/02/26/tech/innovation/dogecoin-cryptocurrency-tech-irpt/|publisher=CNN|accessdate=March 17, 2014}} and has been used in the pornography{{cite news|title=Fox on Reddit: Porn star looks to accept virtual currency Dogecoin|url=http://www.foxnews.com/tech/2014/02/27/fox-on-reddit-porn-star-looks-to-accept-virtual-currency-on-website/|accessdate=March 17, 2014|newspaper=FoxNews.com|date=February 27, 2014}} and poker industries. Dogetipbot was a cryptocurrency transaction service used on popular sites like [[Reddit]] and [[Twitch.tv]]. It allowed users to send Dogecoins to other users through commands via Reddit comments;{{Cite web|url=http://www.coindesk.com/dogetipbot-turned-spoof-altcoin-tipping-phenomenon/|title=How Dogetipbot Turned a Spoof Altcoin into a Tipping Phenomenon|date=2014-04-10|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-14}} support for Twitch.tv and [[Twitter]] had been discontinued earlier. The service was launched in 2013 on Reddit. The trademark "dogetipbot" was officially registered on August 19, 2014.{{Cite web|url=http://tsdr.uspto.gov/documentviewer?caseId=sn86166861&docId=DRW20140120070204|title=USPTO TSDR Case Viewer|website=tsdr.uspto.gov|access-date=2016-07-17}} In November 2014, the developer team behind dogetipbot raised $445,000 in [[venture capital]] funding.{{Cite web|url=http://www.coindesk.com/social-tipping-tool-meme-dogecoin-445k/|title=Micropayments Tool Dogetipbot Wins $445k From Investors|date=2014-11-05|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-14}} In May 2017 Dogetipbot was discontinued and taken offline after its creator declared bankruptcy; this left many Dogetipbot users losing their coins stored in the Dogetipbot system.{{cite web|url=https://gizmodo.com/reddit-users-lose-real-money-after-meme-currency-bot-di-1795125165|title=Reddit Users Lose Real Money After Meme Currency Bot Dies|first=Peter|last=Yeh|publisher=[[Gizmodo]]|date=May 11, 2017}} DogeAPI was a popular early digital wallet for Dogecoins. It was sold in August 2014 to the blockchain API developer Block.io.{{cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/acquisition/block-io-inc--acquires-dogeapi--e85905c3|title= DogeAPI acquired by Block.io, Inc.|publisher=[[Crunchbase]]|date=November 16, 2014}} ==Mining parameters== Dogecoin's implementation differs from [[Litecoin]] by several parameters. Dogecoin's block time is 1 minute as opposed to Litecoin's 2.5 minutes. Several cases of using employer or university computers to mine Dogecoin have been discovered.{{cite news|last1=Hutchinson|first1=Lee|title=Harvard supercomputing cluster hijacked to produce dumb cryptocurrency|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2014/02/harvard-supercomputing-cluster-hijacked-to-produce-alt-cryptocurrency/|accessdate=June 13, 2014|work=Ars technica|publisher=Condé Nast.|date=February 21, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Hern|first1=Alex|title=Student uses university computers to mine Dogecoin|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2014/mar/04/dogecoin-bitcoin-imperial-college-student-mine|accessdate=June 13, 2014|publisher=Guardian.com|date=March 4, 2014}} == Currency supply == Unlike [[deflation]]ary cryptocurrencies which have a limit on the number of coins that can be produced, there is no limit to how many Dogecoins can be produced, which makes it an [[inflation]]ary coin. Dogecoin was initially to have a limit of 100 billion coins, which would already have been far more coins than the top digital currencies were allowing. In February 2014, Dogecoin founder Jackson Palmer announced that that limit would be removed and there would be no cap, which should have the result of constant reduction of its inflation rate over a long time.{{cite web|title=Dogecoin to allow annual inflation of 5 billion coins each year, forever|url=https://arstechnica.com/business/2014/02/dogecoin-to-allow-annual-inflation-of-5-billion-coins-each-year-forever/|publisher=Ars Technica|accessdate=February 4, 2014}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{portal|Business and economics}} * {{Official website}} {{Cryptocurrencies|state=expanded}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Currencies introduced in 2013]] [[Category:Alternative currencies]] [[Category:Cryptocurrencies]] [[Category:Internet memes]] [[Category:Jamaica at the Winter Olympics]] [[Category:2014 Winter Olympics]] [[Category:Computer-related introductions in 2013]]
